newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Australian stocks extend gains by close.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Australian stocks extend gains by close.

text.p: SPI futures 2373 +15 US 30yr cl 6.54 -0.06
*Stocks extend gains by close, lifted by modest bargain hunting after Thursday weakness. Volume 312.94 million shares, value A$652.04 million, 1044 stocks traded, 325 steady, 441 up, 278 down.
Australian shares extended their gains in the afternoon to close higher on Friday as modest bargain hunting emerged after Thursday's weakness.
At 4.10 p.m. (0510 GMT), the All Ordinaries index was 15.4 points higher at 2,362.1. December share index futures were 15 points up at 2,373, a 10.9 point premium to the index.

Brokers said the return of some buying confidence as investors considered the yields on offer had led to a stronger showing after Thursday's perverse reaction to the local interest rate reduction and Wall Street's surge.
"It's quite an improvement," said Robert Cameron of Cameron Securities, adding that the market seemed to be more settled after running ahead of itself prior to Wednesday's rate cut.
"There was probably an overreaction ahead of the interest rate cut. People have settled down and adjusted to it and seen there is still some reasonable yields out there."

Standouts were few, although listed stockbroker McIntosh Securities caught the eye, jumping 15 cents to A$1.25, its highest level since September 1994, on speculation that U.S. broker Merrill Lynch was eyeing it as a takeover target.
Near term outlook was seen mixed with much dependent on how the local market would weather a Wall Street correcting from its current record levels.
Rises outnumbered falls by a ratio of about eight to five, while about 31 percent of stocks traded remained steady.
FUTURES/OPTIONS - Both options and futures trade was at moderate levels only, reflecting the mixed outlook for the underlying market. Total options traded 38,139 (36,672)
Turnover in December SPI contracts totalled 4,152 (8,846)
In other local markets, Australian bonds drifted quietly towards the weekend to end just above this week's 32-month yield lows.
By 5.00 p.m. (0600 GMT), 10 year T-bills were yielding 7.205 percent.

The Australian dollar finished Friday at three month lows as signs of a seismic shift in the Japanese stance on the yen and interest rates struck fear into the heart of high yielding currencies everywhere.
By 5.00 p.m. (0600 GMT), the local currency was quoted at US$0.7835/40.
Short-term range Support Restnce RSI-14 MA-10 MA-20
*Brambles A$22.35 (+.54) 21.85/22.40 Vol: 768,279 Investors buying transport group's positive outlook.
*BHP A$16.70 (+.20) 16.507/16.75 Vol: 6,417,768 Bellwether finds support after Thursday's selldown.
*WMC A$7.56 (-.02) 7.52/7.65 Vol: 4,690,973 Gold/nickel miner finds support early, hits afternoon sellers
Big miner hits lows early after RTZ shares dipped in London after broker downgrade but finds support in afternoon as market closes near day's highs.
*McIntosh A$1.25 (+.15) 1.15/1.25 Vol: 610,000 Takeover speculation sees broker's shares surge.
*News A$7.17 (+.03) 7.14/7.22 Vol: 2,159,723 *Nat Aus Bnk A$13.77 (+.02) 13.74/13.81 Vol: 1,351,770 Industrial leaders benefit from value seekers.
-- Walter Watson 61-2 9373 1800
